etymologies: early 17th century; earliest use found in William Cornwallis (c1579–1614), essayist. From post-classical Latin arrosion-, arrosio from classical Latin arrōs-, past participial stem of arrōdere + -iō

definitions: The action or process of arrode; (also) an instance of this. Also: the state or fact of being worn down or eaten away. Now chiefly in medical contexts.
